paragraphs.title: Event Statistics using Scala
paragraphs.text:
// any import statements go here
import org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD
import org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat
import java.util.Date
import java.net.URL
import java.nio.charset.Charset
import org.apache.spark.sql._

paragraphs.title: Then, load data. We uploaded the data on S3 for easier loading
paragraphs.text:
// load raw data

def loadFromUrl(url:String) = 
    sc.parallelize(
        IOUtils.toString(
            new URL(url),
            Charset.forName("utf8")).split("\n"))
            
val events = loadFromUrl("https://s3.amazonaws.com/6250bdh-hw/hw1/train/events.csv")
val mortality = loadFromUrl("https://s3.amazonaws.com/6250bdh-hw/hw1/train/mortality_events.csv")

paragraphs.title: Event count is defined as the number of events recorded for a given patient
Encounter count is defined as the count of unique dates on which a given patient visited the ICU.

paragraphs.text:
val (min_dead_event_count, max_dead_event_count, avg_dead_event_count, min_alive_event_count, max_alive_event_count, avg_alive_event_count) = 
event_count_metrics(eventsRDD, mortalityRDD)
paragraphs.title: Testing Event Count - Don't change this cell
Populate the correct values in df_events dataframe
Plot Event Count Grouped by Dead/Alive
Testing Encounter Count - Don't change any cell starting from this one
paragraphs.text: val  (avg_dead_encounter_count, max_dead_encounter_count, min_dead_encounter_count, avg_alive_encounter_count, max_alive_encounter_count, min_alive_encounter_count) = encounter_count_metrics(eventsRDD, mortalityRDD)
